I have installed and uninstalled this game time and time again.
The concept is very unique and you're faced with unpalatable choices.
Yet this game isn't for the casual player. Time and time again, I find myself incredibly frustrated given the lack of breathing room. 
Playing on easy settings, with a customized map, just to get familiar with the mechanics, sees the weather jump to -70 after several turns.

This isn't a strategy game - it's rather a "make the right choice" and survive until the next round. Once you learn by trial and error the correct sequence of choices, then the game is reduced to a series of predetermined moves with the same outcome.

The game is too masochistic to be enjoyed. There needs to be a balance between reward/risk without turning off the player with a consistent barrage of challenges.

Absolute legend of a city builder. Engaging enough to play through scenarios at least twice. There are two different paths (Order or Faith) of discourse management you can take. Admittedly once you go through each of these once regardless of the scenario you are playing, you've exhausted the shiny new option feeling of the choices each branch gives you. You have different moral options available (outside of the Order/Faith branches), in a way that lets you play it mostly neutral, or an extremity of either dictatorial or benevolent leadership depending on your inclination. There's enough nuance in these choices that the game is worth playing if you enjoy city builders that have a good balance of micro and macro management aspects (you decide where citizens work in what concentration in order to adjust your resource profits in a way that fits the scenario and playstyle you've chosen, as well as deciding which/how many of each type of building to make/upgrade). 

Essentially if you enjoy macro/micro strategy games that have bullet point goals to achieve throughout a playthrough and/or are looking for a city management game that has a melancholy atmosphere, you'll enjoy the game. I've written this on a whim after the sequel game has come out, but as a newcomer to the genre I'd say it's worth playing this game before delving into the sequel.

Frostpunk is a relatively challenging and interesting entry into the city builder genre. 

It intentionally forces tough moral and ethical choices in the name of keeping humankind alive and forces deeper evaluation of whether the ends justify the means, even in such dire circumstances. Sure, enforcing child labor or any number of other unethical choices may make colony life easier, but at what cost? Could the colony have survived otherwise? The game is unflinching in its judgement.

Frostpunk is first and foremost a resource management game, and the colony is nearly always under the gun from some sort of pressure. That pressure comes in the form of deficiencies in resources, manpower, research, or social cohesion. The tension is maintained by a variety of twists and turns over the course of a scenario that require on-the-fly adjustments.

I would highly recommend Frostpunk for those interested in a challenging resource management city builder.

A great city builder focused on survival against the elements instead, of any kind of military threat.

The tightly built systems of the game make it almost a kind of puzzle game as opposed to your typical 4x game.

Although I recommend Frostpunk, and think it's quite good.  I do think it won't be for everyone for the very reasons above.

Because the game is so carefully balanced in order to make just existing in the environment itself a challenge, the game is a frantic race against time.  I never had an over abundance of resources till the last few days, where the resources didn't matter anymore.  I ignore wide parts of the tech tree in order to do what felt like the most important basics to live.  I also restarted about 5 times at the start of the game, because build order of day 1 is critical.

That's all to say, the game is pretty stressful.  This isn't a cozy game, nor can you really sit back and let it play itself, you need to actively min-max which is unusal in the genre.

On the other hand, if you find cozy city builders boring and too easy - this is the game for you.

We marched for days... finding solace within the frozen depths of a berg with an old generator. It was a sight for sore eyes. Yet.. the captain... the fire in his eyes burned hotter and far brighter than the inferno keeping our bones warm. He mumbled something, ordering coal mines to be built and signing off on a law... Our Children put to work in hot houses to help feed us.. at least it is a safe job.

I'm off to the Workshop. We've been ordered to research a weather balloon to scout the Ice Shelf for potential survivors... though I worry with the Captain mentioning Children as top priority.. he's been harassing the council to push a new law, yet we've only just arrived. I worry for what storms brews within his mind.

Our children... occupying the mines whilst Foreman whip them to make them work... everything is run by the small hands of our children... and yet my fellow Englishman watch and do naught. The "peace keepers", as some have mentioned themselves to be, enforce these cruel laws... is this the price of prayer for the Sun to rise and warm our bones for but a moment? Heavens save our children, for our Captain will not.

This game is intense, the art is insane, and the opening scenes give me chills. I feel so much purpose over these fictional people and feel the pain of my law decisions. Rating: 8/10

Frostpunk is a gripping city-builder with a unique survival twist, where every decision has real consequences. Managing resources in a frozen wasteland while trying to keep the last remnants of humanity alive creates a constant sense of urgency. The choices are tough—balancing hope and despair, deciding whether to be a benevolent leader or a strict authoritarian. These decisions don’t just shape your city’s development; they force you to confront the morality behind every choice.

The gameplay is incredibly rewarding, with each scenario offering distinct challenges that test your management skills in different ways. Whether you’re dealing with limited coal, struggling to keep the generator running, or facing food shortages, there’s always something pushing you to adapt and find creative solutions. The difficulty curve is steep, but that’s part of what makes the game so satisfying. Frostpunk doesn’t hold your hand—it forces you to think ahead and manage crises with limited resources.

The mechanics are polished and intuitive, making it easy to get lost in the game’s world. Each new technology unlocks exciting possibilities, and the city-building aspect feels smooth and responsive. However, some of the achievements are a bit too demanding, requiring a level of precision and replayability that can be overwhelming for more casual players.

As for the DLCs, they are well worth diving into, each expanding the game’s scope in meaningful ways. However, after a while, the core gameplay can start to feel a bit repetitive. By the time I had explored all the content, I was ready to move on.

Personally, Frostpunk was a game that kept me hooked for a long time. I enjoyed the challenge, the tough decisions, and the bleak atmosphere, but I see no reason to go back to it now. Some of the achievements were just too much for me, and while the experience was deeply rewarding, it’s one I’m happy to close the book on. Now, I’m excited to see what the sequel brings!

Game has a really good base, but it's terribly unbalanced. 
- The AI is unbelievably stupid, generally preventing you from making better decisions because for some reason survivors of the apocalypse don't understand that they won't always get their way.
- Weather changes are random, so there's little skill involved with beating the weather, and mostly luck.
- It's always a race against time, always trying to find one shoddy patchwork solution after the next, that again is based on luck and very little on skill because negative events are random.
- Timed deadlines are arbitrary. Instead of making a certain amount of progress over the course of weeks or months, perhaps leading up to an incoming event (like how the main storyline goes), in the secondary stories you MUST create an entirely  post-apocalyptic civilization in less than 4 weeks, otherwise you are a terrible ruler and your people will overthrow you and end you :) makes total sense.

As long as the game remains in a state of balance where I could complete the game on Extreme difficulty if I get a lucky enough start, the game will not be good. It needs a full rebalance, or rather mod support, but with Frostpunk 2 out, this game has been sunset and there's no reason to buy it, kept in this garbage state.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] Great fun for a while, but becomes boring too quickly. Also the UI / UX / usability aspects are underdeveloped. Thumbs up because it is brilliant for about 10 hours, then this game tends to waste your time. You will notice the little annoying details where it needed more polishing.

[b]Full Take:[/b]
Getting started is too hard. As soon as you know how to stabilize your city, it's very good for a couple of hours, and this is where this game truly shines. You can spend an entire night to binge it and that's great. Having success and expanding feels very rewarding. But towards the end of a scenario, there is not much left to do. It becomes very stale. So the pacing of the gameplay is not equally spread. Early, mid and late game should be more similar in terms of difficulty, activities and decisions to make. Also the random events sometimes can make it too hard or too easy.
The worst and most annoying part of this game is the presentation:
- The buildings look too similar. It's hard to distinguish them.
- Economy needs more details. I was disappointed when I couldn't get a nice table of the data.
- No clear arrangement of structures: you cannot quickly highlight all medical / storage / industrial buildings, houses, etc.
- For example, when there are a lot of ill people in your city, there is no quick way to show in which medical facility the patients are. You have to click through every building. Then you have to click the special healing ability in each of the buildings. There should be a more convenient way. This leads to some annoying clicking work when you want to micro-manage.
- There should be more automation in terms of micro-managing. Like "automatically turn on heating in a building when it's cold".
- The circular grid around your central generator is a nice idea, but the implementation is lackluster, especially considering the weird sizes of the buildings.

[b]Final Thought:[/b]
The first ~10 hours are awesome, then are many annoying details that you will notice the longer you play. Have fun but quit before you start sinking too much valuable time into the boredom to come.

I completed all the main scenarios and the DLC on normal setting.  What makes Frostpunk superior as a strategy game compared to say Age of Empires II, is that:

(a) the overview map is mostly circular around the central generator hub and is visible on the screen at all times.
(b) you can zoom in and view any of your people in this bleak frosty world at any time.
(c) there is no combat, which means that the game has a simplicity in the number of resources you need to manage (coal, wood) and there are usually only two major unit types (workers, engineers).
(d) the overarching narrative of survival against the odds, works well in driving you forward.  Each of the scenarios has set events (e.g. weather, injury, disease, riots) that you have to manage, keeping you engrossed from the start to mid game to end game of each scenario.
(e) there is a beauty in the cold, frosty climate with warm glow of the central generator.
(f) there is an ease of making all commands with its accessible User Interface (UI),

Really sad I didn't try this game out years ago, and this is one more piece of evidence to my theory that indie gaming really had a golden age in the 2015-2018 range.  If you had released it this year it would have been one of my favorites to come out.  It's a city manager but really takes some of the basics of the genre in a different direction.  The conceit of fighting against this oncoming frozen apocalypse creates some interesting decision making about how you heat and layout your colony, use coal, who is out in the cold and who isn't, and preparing for changing weather and unexpected events.

The thing I like most about this, in most similar games you have all of these buildings like resource storage and medical facilities and ways to mitigate disaster that if you're good, you just aren't using, you should be keeping your resources spent enough you don't have to waste any on building storage facilities, if you screwed something up and significant numbers are getting sick, you need to reload something further back because you've started a downward spiral you just should have avoided.  In this game, people are getting sick.  You feel the winter in this game, people are being sent out into a cold where some of them are going to come back in bad shape, your question isn't if your hospitals are going to be overflowing capacity, but how much of your resources are you going to spend trying to save a few more people and how shady are you going to get trying to mitigate the problem.  How many groups of refugees are you turning away, are you using child labor so you can get the heat up sooner, are you going to just euthanize those that are probably not going to make it anyway to free up the beds for people who are going to die without help.

The game has a boom and bust cycle, if you send out scouts you can't be sure what they're going to find in the wasteland when exploring, weather patterns change your current needs, events and some plot points can hit you with unexpected issues, and so on, so essential to the game is taking advantage when things are good and burning through resources and making due when things are bad, and timing that right and planning for the unknown unknowns are critical.  Every time I would think "oh well the game wouldn't do that to me" it is the kind of game that definitely will do that to you, but in a way that's reasonable, not in a random punishing way but like, "yeah it makes sense the refugees I agreed to help were almost all sick and unable to work when they arrived after trudging for weeks through wasteland" or "yeah it makes sense the first time I sent people out to fix that thing it didn't work and now I need to rip another one of my critical buildings apart to get another steam core if I want to try again."  Reasonable, but unfair.

You're playing well outside the colony management playbook, almost imagine another colony sim game where you've definitely lost, you're watching everything fall apart, but for whatever reason you've just stubbornly decided you're not reloading, you're going to play out the save to the bitter end, and you're pulling off every tricky bs move you can think of to make things last just a little bit longer, deconstructing some buildings, move some people around, intentionally letting some of your population die if you have to, wildly spend resources to keep things going, make deals with the devil if you have to just to get a few more days, that's the perpetual state you are in from the moment you start until the end.  This also has the side effect of making it a self balancing game, i.e., the game is a lot easier if you just turn away almost everyone and generally be as unethical as possible, but how much boyscout nonsense can you get away with before you've doomed everyone, remembering, again, that the game will not be even handed with you.

It also has a bunch of additional scenarios after you complete the main game that are quite good.  I think the replay value on the main campaign would hold up reasonably well, the fact that there's a half a dozen extra scenarios that feel like they could almost be seperate solid games is amazing, which change up your starting situation in interesting ways and give you a different plot and events and local wasteland to explore, like starting out with a colony of all scientists trying to keep a seed bank from freezing which limits the kinds of jobs you can do but changes your priorities considerably (no one has to live! your goal is to automate), or playing a group of revolutionaries who will refuse to turn away anyone.
Do you like city builders and stress?!  This one is for you.  All kidding aside its a really good game that is challenging and visually striking.  10/10

Frostpunk Review: Surviving the Cold (Mostly)

Rating: 8.0 out of 10.0

I finally dove into Frostpunk after it sat on my watchlist for far too long, and boy, was I in for a cold slap in the face. The game looked daunting—overly complicated, slow, and definitely not for beginners. Spoiler: all of that’s true. But despite its harsh learning curve, it’s an experience worth the struggle. Cold, challenging, and deeply satisfying—Frostpunk is the survival game you didn’t know you needed.


Pros: "The Warm Glow of Victory"
+ Simple Yet Engaging Strategy: At its core, Frostpunk is a city-building sim, but it’s dressed in survival-horror clothing. It taps into that SimCity-loving part of you, with just enough dystopia to keep you hooked.
+ Addictive Gameplay Loop: Once you crack the tough mechanics, the game becomes hard to put down. The constant battle for survival keeps you on edge, always coming back for "just one more day."
+ Scenario Variety: If you’re ready to throw in the towel on one campaign, you can jump into different scenarios, offering a nice change of pace without starting over entirely.
+ Unique Strategic Decision-Making: Every choice matters, and it often feels like you’re weighing the survival of your entire population with each decision.

Cons: "The Bitter Winds of Defeat"
– Daunting Learning Curve: This game doesn’t care if you’re new or if you read the manual. It’ll drop you straight into the cold without so much as a guide, leaving you to Google your way through basic tasks.
– Clunky UI: The interface can feel unintuitive. Trying to figure out why your buildings are freezing despite being in a heater’s radius can drive you mad. Expect a lot of "trial and error" moments.
– Frustrating Mechanics: Sometimes, no matter how well you think you're managing things, it feels like you’re fighting an uphill battle. The game seems to enjoy watching you squirm.

Neutral: "The Permafrost of Repetition"
+/- Scenario Similarity: While there are several scenarios to choose from, after a while they start to feel pretty similar. It's still cold, you're still struggling, and the mechanics don’t change much from one to the next.

Verdict:
Frostpunk is a tough but rewarding strategy game. It’s not beginner-friendly, and the UI can be a hassle, but once you push through the initial frustration, the sense of accomplishment is immense. If you’re into city-building with a dark survival twist, this game will keep you hooked. Just be ready for a steep learning curve and a few moments of rage.

Holy crap, I just realised that I've never reviewed this game in over five years since I first played it. Anyway, on with it then.

Frostpunk is, to my knowledge, one of if not the first kind of survival city-builder games on the market. Many city-builder games generally tend to focus on the building mechanics, with some occasionally featuring a military element here and there.

This game has none of that. Though building placement is a main feature, the key drive is to keep your settlement alive in the frozen wastelands by maintaining the Generator, a marvel of Victorian-era technology and the last symbol of the dying British Empire's power before the world became shrouded in snow.

Frostpunk's main campaign scenario sees you trying to keep your settlement intact as its residents brace themselves for the Great Storm. In addition to harvesting resources, you're confronted with difficult choices that can negatively impact the populace's level of hope. Should discontent rise high enough, exile to a frosty death in the wastelands is your end.

The other campaign scenarios tend to be shorter, but are no less impactful, as they deal with the circumstances that are adjacent to the main one. In the case of The Last Autumn DLC, you have to build the Generator before the Great Frost sets in.

The game's other mechanics are also of interest. Heat, of course, is the main thing that keeps everything in working order. Having to keep everybody warm enough against the amount of coal you can mine is one of the more challenging aspects. Similarly, feeding the populace and ensuring they don't fall ill too frequently will grind your gears in the early part of a given scenario, and practically throughout all of it if you choose to play on the higher difficulties.

The research for newer buildings & passive effects is relatively simple enough (compared to Frostpunk 2's system) but you can get stuck should you lack the sufficient resources to do so. And scouting is a matter of both luck and timing, lest your exploration teams perish in the frostlands. 

Perhaps the most interesting aspect of the game is its Book of Laws. The Purpose laws are generally immediate in their effects, while the Adaptation laws take time to do so. While Purpose's impact is generally benign, one ought to be careful when dealing with Adaptation. The right number of laws will serve to benefit your society, but go too far and it can spiral out of your control.

All in all, Frostpunk is a unique twist on a saturated genre. The only drawback is that developer 11 Bit Studios did not make the game moddable, which is a shame as it would've greatly extended the game's replayability. I gathered that they've somewhat addressed this in Frostpunk 2 with a modkit. Hopefully, if Frostpunk 3 ever gets made, they return back to the basics but this time with modding features.

It's fun, but I struggled to keep playing it after two or three scenarios. I wasn't actually sure why, the atmosphere is great, the OST is awesome and the gameplay is solid, but then I realized that the difficulty is 100% based on "did you build the right thing in anticipation of what the game will throw at you next?" which is knowledge you can only acquire by repeatedly playing the game. You need to know ahead of time how cold things are going to get, how you can ensure you have enough coal stored to heat everyone, the exact number of hunters/farmers needed to keep the city fed, where you can find more steam cores/extra citizens...

As a result, playing the game feels almost masochistic, as the game punishes you for not being aware of events that happen in the future due to a lack of experience, as gathering resources and building structures is too slow to manage your city reactively. This forces you to restart your game, try things out until you get past the hurdle that killed your city last time, then you hit the next hurdle, where the process repeats itself until you get past the scenario. Then you can either try a different scenario or up the difficulty.

Like I said, the atmosphere alone is a reason to play this game, but you're going to struggle to enjoy playing through every bit of content the game has. I for one got pretty tired of trying a new scenario, then getting shot in the proverbial leg for not knowing I needed a specific setup to get past the next temperature drop and being unable to recover because all my citizens were now mad at me.

Strengths:
Outstanding Atmosphere and World-Building: Frostpunk excels at conveying the bleakness and coldness of its world. The game’s artistic graphics, combined with its unique sound design, fully immerse the player in the frozen, desperate world.

Challenging Gameplay: The game strikes a good balance between resource management and ethical decision-making. Every decision you make about allocating resources or setting city priorities can have significant consequences, forcing the player to always think strategically.

Strong Story and Ethical Dilemmas: The game’s narrative and random events fit well with the gameplay. You are given the ability to enact different laws that directly affect your community, but many of these decisions lead to moral dilemmas, adding depth to the game.

Exceptional Resource Management Design: Managing vital resources like food, coal, and manpower is cleverly designed, requiring the player to carefully decide how to allocate limited resources in the most effective way.

Weaknesses:
Steep Difficulty Curve: The gameplay may feel overly difficult and frustrating for some players. Even with careful strategies, the game can be unpredictable and challenging, which might lead to frustration for some.

Repetitive Challenges: While the initial ethical and strategic decisions are engaging, after a while, some of these decisions and challenges may feel repetitive, which could reduce the depth of the gameplay.

Lack of Variety in Modes: The game focuses on limited modes, and once the scenarios are completed, the gameplay potential feels somewhat limited. Post-release content has addressed this issue to an extent, but more variety could still have enhanced the experience.

Conclusion:
Frostpunk is a standout game in the survival and resource management genre, presenting players with a dark and challenging world. Despite some drawbacks like limited content variety and steep difficulty, the game offers a unique and engaging experience thanks to its strong atmosphere, exceptional artistic design, and strategic gameplay.

Происходящее отдает неприкрытым идиотизмом с самого начала, когда нам показывают печку Емели на стероидах и бредущих куда-то людей. Ехать внутри чудо-теплушки? Залезть на броню? Хотя бы сделать пару шагов в сторону и идти по проделанной колее? Нет, мы будем ковылять к светлому будущему по сугробам до подбородка!

Итак, выжившие [spoiler]из ума[/spoiler] добрались до какого-то кратера с непонятной целью, непонятно как спустили теплушку, непонятно как спустились сами. И ради чего все это? Почему нельзя было остаться в городе? Там, может, тоже холодно, зато мародерствовать проще, а стены зданий защищают от ветра. Но нет, в палатках в жопе мира местным шизикам почему-то лучше.

Зачем было забираться туда, где волки срать боятся (в буквальном смысле - в игре вы не встретите ни одного срущего волка)? Откуда вокруг взялись аккуратные кучки ресурсов, которые даже снегом не запорошило? Так много вопросов и совсем нет ответов.

Дальше больше. В качестве центрального здания люди строят огромную печь, которая обогревает все, кроме домов. Хватит греть воздух, проложите трубопровод в здания! Металл для этого имеется. Делать мы этого не будем, но можем построить мини-печки посреди улицы, которые тоже будут греть воздух.

Отдельный маразм - это очень короткий рабочий день. Люди делают все, чтобы сдохнуть. Дело происходит в Англии в конце XX века, когда 8-часовой рабочий день вводился лишь локально и в рамках экспериментов. В реальности нормой были рабочий день в 12 часов, несколько смен и детский труд. Нарубить угля ночью? Давать детям посильные задачи с самого начала? Напрячься, чтобы не голодать и быть в тепле? Нет, мы лучше будем ворчать на нашего лидера и сдохнем! А когда начнем дохнуть, то разозлимся на лидера еще сильнее, что он нас не уберег. Хорошо хоть, что люди не требуют выходных и праздников.

Неумение строить большинство зданий намекает на то, что мы управляем пещерными людьми. Они могут поставить палатки, но не могут сделать нормальный сруб, для этого нужно исследовать несколько технологий. Дороги не имеют смысла. Какова их цель? Грамотно распределять ресурсы? Нет, дороги бесплатные. Упростить жизнь людям, прокладывая оптимальные маршруты? Так они все равно не пользуются дорогами и чешут напролом через сугробы.

Законы можно выпускать только с определенной периодичностью, их нельзя отменять, а некоторые законы друг другу противоречат по непонятной причине. Например, нельзя обучить часть детей инженерному делу, а часть первой помощи. Либо все дети инженерят, либо клизмы ставят, третьего не дано.

Социальная составляющая игры - отдельное дно. У взрослых есть 2 гендера - рабочий и инженер. Речь идет не о современности, когда инженер и рабочий должны понимать базовые задачи друг друга. Речь идет о конце XIX века, когда инженер был редким и образованным кадром, а рабочий дешевой низкоквалифицированной силой. В игре же вся разница между этими категориями в том, что инженеры могут исследовать и лечить, а рабочие охотиться. Да и сами инженеры не редкие и ценные, как ожидается с самого начала.

Кстати, о людях. Это ресурс, и не более того. Разработчики наделили каждого болванчика именем, но по факту это просто еще один ресурс. Индивидуальности между поселенцами нет с самого начала, а когда их количество переваливает за 200, ее становится еще меньше.

Экспедиции проводятся с помощью воздушного шара, чьей вместительности позавидует любая маршрутка в час пик. У меня в одной корзине запросто помещается 5 человек из экспедиции, 30 с лишним беженцев, более сотни единиц ресурсов (наверное, это несколько тонн) и какой-то чудо-модуль для строительства крутых зданий. При этом никто из этих людей не замерзает, не ест, не болеет и появляется в лагере всегда в отличном состоянии.

Очень странно, что почти обойден стороной вопрос удобства. Недостаток домов только снижает настроение людей, но я не заметил, чтобы ночующие на улицах чаще болели. Одежда так вообще отсутствует, хотя сама идея игры весьма определенно подталкивает к ее введению.

После преодоления первого кризиса в поселении появляется группа враждебно настроенных лондонцев. Они говорят "здесь живется плохо, давайте свалим обратно в Лондон по холоду и сугробам без возможности обогреться туда, где мы точно не выживем", а люди им отвечают [spoiler]"А давайте!"[/spoiler]. Вы думаете, лондонцы просто соберут манатки и свалят? Да щас! Они еще две недели будут жить в поселении, ныть и изредка избивать патрульных, продолжая при этом добросовестно работать на предприятиях.

Люди начинают замерзать в -20, а в -50 им даже в домах холодно. Непроизвольно возникает вопрос - как же в Сибири на воздухе работают примерно при таком же диапазоне температур? Причем в игре температура всегда кратна 10 градусам, нет никаких плавных изменений, только резкие аномальные перепады. А температура под -100 окончательно превращает происходящее в какой-то анекдот про совершенно другую планету.

Но я все сюжет и атмосферу, хотя видно, что их даже не пытались создать. Поговорим про геймплей, ведь ради него обычно и покупают игры. А он тут устарел лет на 20. Помните старые экономические стратегии Caesar, Pharaoh, Zeus? Помните, как надо было решать сиюминутные проблемы поселения, одновременно думая над грамотной застройкой районов и организации логистики? Помните, как надо было расставлять приоритеты? Во Фростпанке геймплей примитивен до невозможности - если не хватает жилых домов, строим жилые дома. Не хватает ресурсов - добываем ресурсы. Холодно - исследуем технологию "как положить дрова в костер". Не нужно пытаться удовлетворить разные слои населения и не нужно думать о застройке, достаточно ставить здания как попало.

Старые экономические стратегии сейчас устарели, но для своего времени многие из них были весьма неплохи и оригинальны, а здесь у нас просто примитивная и кособокая головоломка. Все здания/приказы/исследования делятся на суперкрупые, адекватные и бесполезные, но вы не знаете, что вам пригодится наперед, пока не станет слишком поздно. Есть только одна верная стратегия, и отклонение от нее усложняет жизнь. Короче, над балансом здесь работали так же, как над сюжетом.

Ну ладно, перейдем к плюсам. Их можно пересчитать по пальцам одной руки рабочего из игры, у которого половина пальцев уже отморожена. Плюс первый - это оптимизация. Системные требования адекватные, загрузки быстрые, что сейчас является большой редкостью. Плюс второй - оформление. Звуковое сопровождение хорошее, картинка приятная глазу.

Вердикт. Представьте пазл, который вы должны собрать с закрытыми глазами на ощупь. В первый раз это унылая игра в угадайку, во второй раз играть не хочется. Впрочем, если вам нравится смотреть на людей, которые демонстративно страдают, то это может даже зайти.

This is one of those games that will stick to your memory for years.

It is like the sweet nostalgia when you think about playing videogames as a kid back in the day.

Frostpunk combines many elements to form the game it is. It has survival, heavy resource management, decision making that affect your town and also a law system that further shapes your town (or more like survival pit) and can affect your people.

The immersion is outstanding, from the world, to the UI and a big factor for me, the music, plunge you in this time-critical game where your decisions matter and where there is never enough time to fully prepare yourself to survive what is coming. Some may consider this game stressful. I do too, but in a very good way.

Even though the game only has a set amount of scenarios that you can play through (and also an endless mode), I have never got bored of repeating said scenarios as every play-through kept me at the same level of scrambling for time to manage and gather my resources and develop for the upcoming temperature drops.

Worth every penny even at full price however, the developers sometimes offer it as good discount as well.

- Audio pops/glitches. First time in my life I had audio issues in a game.
- Stuttering during the 2D cinematic scenes in a game from 6 years ago in a Ryzen 9 7950X + RTX 3070 computer.. The main game runs fine so it's a bug on their side instead of hardware specification.
- Interface glitches like resetting animations when opening a menu (which also triggers the audio pops issue). The interface is so polished I don't know how they missing a bug like this in menu we open all the time.
Maybe it's something with the GOTY version but the game feels buggy.

I could even ignore these annoyances but the game isn't good as a survival/base-building. There is not a lot of freedom or map exploration you would expect from this genre. It's more of a politics management puzzle with a base-building gimmick which is slow and the progression is somewhat scripted if you want to survive. It's a shame because they really nailed the visuals and atmosphere. Most game interfaces nowadays are so bland and basic, this level of polishment is very hard to see.

I heard that Frostpunk 2 improves on the base-building, for the dismiss of who liked the politics management/puzzle stuff, but it sounds much better to me. I'll probably try the sequence instead.

Frostpunk is a unique blend of city-building and survival strategy that forces you to make tough decisions in a brutal, frozen world. The game’s atmosphere is intense, with its bleak visuals and haunting soundtrack drawing you into a constant struggle for survival.

The mechanics are well-balanced, combining resource management with moral dilemmas that challenge your leadership. Every choice matters, whether it’s enacting harsh laws or deciding who gets the last rations. It’s a game that rewards strategic planning but punishes hesitation.

Overall, "Frostpunk" delivers a gripping, thought-provoking experience that keeps you on the edge. If you’re looking for a game that tests your resolve and leadership, this is a must-play.

My video essay on the base game + my much shorter thoughts on the DLCs.

How Frostpunk Injects Harrowing Moral Choices into the City Builder Genre: https://youtu.be/G9RDldztjTw?si=p13Qnf8uu_yDxlag

-The Fall of Winterhome:
Pretty brief and rather similar to the base campaign but it ramps up the challenge in a couple of unique ways and is satisfying to overcome

-The Last Autumn:
The best and most complete-feeling of the DLCs. They really weren't holding back when they made this one. It's like a whole game on its own. They almost could have called this Frostpunk 2, though it would definitely be a lateral move instead of the full evolution that the actual Frostpunk 2 seems to be shaping up as.

The Last Autumn shakes up the core game's mechanics in interesting ways, most notably by almost entirely ditching the temperature mechanic that defines Frostpunk in large part. It sounds like a game that revolves around temperature management ditching the temperature management for the DLC would be a huge mistake, but they pulled it off by introducing enough new conflicts and factors to keep things interesting.

If there's anything that holds it back a bit for me, it's that it's a little on the easy side as far as Frostpunk goes (though I see plenty of people felt the opposite, so I won't hold that against the game — beating the main game and the Fall of Winterhome scenario right beforehand may have over-prepared me). I finished the main objective a full 10 days ahead of schedule and knocked out all of the bonus objectives too with plenty of time to spare. I don't think the game was prepared for me to run things so efficiently because I had nothing left to do for the final 5+ days and ended up just leaving it on fast-forward until the ending arrived. Not an exciting note to end on, which stood in stark contrast to the main campaign and the Fall of Winterhome scenario that both had nail-biting finales. Still super fun and engaging, and an extremely impressive display of ingenuity to reconfigure the game's systems into such a drastically different experience.

-On the Edge:
It's truly impressive how these developers were able to find so many new ways to utilize the same core mechanics while consistently upping the difficulty and making things feel fresh, though this one did seem to peak in difficulty early on while the climax was far easier in comparison

Never has a video game made me question and confront both my morals and moral philosophy in general. In any city builder game I’ve felt like a detached almost godlike figure, but in Frostpunk I feel connected. When I do something that people like, I feel accomplished and that I am their savior. Beyond the stories (the DLCs are also excellent with The Last Autumn being the best and most unique) the gameplay itself is smooth and refined. The art and score are amazing. At a glance, I thought frostpunk would be a game with nihilistic themes, a city builder like any other where after time, tedium kicks in and overspreading metropolises become boring. A sim city or cities skyline in a fancy piece of clothing to obfuscate it.

I was very very wrong.

This game kicks away from those tropes with mechanics, narrative and decisions I haven't seen anywhere else in the genre. Never have I felt so empathetic towards the population of such a game.

In the end, you're not just laying down blocks in a city, you're making choices in the hope that you can keep your population in line, in the hope that you might save others, in the hope that you can keep children safe and out of harms way, in the hope  that your people will live to see another day, another day, another day.

another day.

Frostpunk is a pretty complex game that requires a lot of managing short term problems while trying to plan for the long term and any lack of planning in either regard will either wreck your run early in or have it collapse in the end as you try to manage an ongoing crisis

--And I love it. I love the way that this game makes you think strategically even if it doesn't exactly require the most creative planning. I think this game also succeeds in creating a very fragile balancing act between the end of the world and whether or not the player decides to maintain the societal norms that existed in a world where order and organization were the backbone of civilization, and it's also a game where often the most moral solution isn't the right one. For example, ceremonial burials will make people happy and retain some normalcy in the most dire times, but if you dump them in a pit and freeze them for use as either organ donors or fertilizer, you'll provide a much needed service to your people. Or cramming people into crowded hospitals. It might not make them happy, but when everyone is frostbitten, ill, and on the edge, it makes sense

My major complaint with this game (aside from performance) is that the scale kind of boxes you in and prevents creative thinking. Most runs of each major scenario are likely to play out in a similar way, and when you've played it multiple times, it eventually all becomes second nature which isn't exactly something you want in a game like this. Especially on "A New Home." You rush overcrowding, rush to the automaton, mechanize the city, end with 650 people, and it's over.

Still, everything from the sound design and music to the world building, visuals, and the way the game requires quick thinking are done phenomenally, and I would recommend this game to anyone, even if they  aren't necessarily fans of RTS/city builders, because that applied to me and I still had a lot of fun.

C H I L D L A B O U R

Frostpunk is a masterclass in combining city-building with survival strategy, offering a compelling and often nerve-wracking experience. One of the game's strongest features is its replayability. The missions are designed in such a way that, even after completing them, you can return with a different strategy and face new challenges. The procedural nature of the events and the way the environment responds to your choices mean no two playthroughs are exactly alike. Each time I’ve gone back to a scenario, I’ve found something fresh that has kept me on edge, forcing me to adapt and reconsider my tactics.

The city-building mechanics are highly intuitive but complex enough to demand your full attention. Managing resources, keeping your people warm, and ensuring their survival all require you to balance short-term needs against long-term sustainability. What I particularly enjoyed is the game's pacing when it comes to resource management. Resources are always scarce, but they’re never so limited that you feel helpless—just tight enough to force critical decisions. You’re constantly operating on the edge, and that creates a level of tension that drives the whole experience forward.

Another standout aspect is the moral and ethical dilemmas the game throws at you. As the leader of a frozen colony struggling to survive, you're often forced to make decisions that can be brutal. Whether it's enacting child labor laws to keep the coal mines running or deciding whether to provide more care houses for the sick, every choice affects the morale and survival of your people. These dilemmas are not just there for shock value; they add depth to the city-building mechanics and make you consider the human cost of your decisions.

Visually, Frostpunk’s bleak, frozen world is beautifully rendered, with the cold feeling palpable as your city expands. Watching your city slowly grow into a bustling hub of survival amidst the desolation is incredibly satisfying, and it gives the game an atmospheric edge that pulls you into its harsh reality.

All in all, if you’re someone who loves strategy games with real consequences, detailed city-building mechanics, and a touch of survival, Frostpunk offers an experience that’s challenging, thought-provoking, and endlessly replayable. The balance of difficulty and reward, combined with its strong narrative elements, makes it a standout title in the genre. It’s one of those games that keeps you coming back, trying to do better, trying to survive just one more storm.

[h1]Detailed review:[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]What It Is:[/b][/td]
[td]
🌟 [b]Society Survival at Its Best:[/b] Guide the last city on Earth through a frozen apocalypse, making life-or-death decisions to ensure humanity's survival.

🔥 [b]Emotional and Moral Depth:[/b] Every choice carries a weight. Whether it's deciding to enact child labor or rationing resources, your decisions shape the fate of your society.

🎯 [b]Comprehensive Management:[/b] Oversee resources like coal, wood, steel, and food to keep your people alive, balancing their hope and discontent.

🎨 [b]Atmospheric Frozen World:[/b] Stunningly bleak visuals immerse you in a world where every snowflake feels like a reminder of your people's fragility.

⚙️ [b]Multiple Playstyles:[/b] Adapt to different playthroughs using unique strategies for each scenario and difficulty level.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🌟[b]Overview:[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]"Frostpunk" is a survival city-building game where players lead a group of survivors in a frozen wasteland. Your objective is to manage resources, build infrastructure, and keep the city warm. The game is built on the foundation of difficult decisions, with each choice potentially leading to the salvation or downfall of your people. The emotional weight of your leadership will be tested as you balance progress and morality.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🎮[b]Gameplay:[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
Take on the mantle of the leader of the last human city in a world trapped in an eternal winter. In "Frostpunk," your city-building and management skills will be challenged at every turn as you make difficult decisions to ensure survival.

🌍 [b]Exploration:[/b] Send out scouts to explore the frozen wasteland, uncover lost technologies, and bring back vital supplies.

🔧 [b]Laws and Society:[/b] Shape your city through lawmaking—will you be a benevolent ruler, or will survival push you to the extremes of authoritarianism?

🤝 [b]Societal Management:[/b] Keep your citizens alive and hopeful while managing their discontent. Fail, and rebellion or despair may follow.

💥 [b]Survival at All Costs:[/b] From gathering resources to handling moral dilemmas, each day brings a new challenge to keeping your people warm and fed.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]📖[b]Story and Depth:[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
Set in a post-apocalyptic world where a volcanic winter has wiped out most of humanity, "Frostpunk" places you in charge of rebuilding society. The game's story explores themes of survival, hope, and morality. Players must decide what lengths they will go to in order to save the last remnants of humanity, making each decision an emotional test of their leadership. The deep narrative threads together personal sacrifices and societal consequences, with multiple scenarios offering varied stories and challenges.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🏆[b]Verdict:[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
"Frostpunk" is a masterclass in survival strategy. Its blend of intense city management and moral decision-making creates a game where every choice feels impactful. The stunningly cold, atmospheric visuals and gripping story immerse players in a world where heat equals life. Whether you're a fan of strategy, city-building, or emotional storytelling, "Frostpunk" offers a unique and unforgettable experience.

While the pressure may be overwhelming at times, the reward is in mastering the challenge of survival in the harshest conditions imaginable. The game's multiple scenarios and endless mode provide lasting replayability, making "Frostpunk" a must-play for fans of strategic survival games.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]✅[b]Good:[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
👍 [b]Emotionally charged decision-making:[/b] Every choice carries significant weight and emotional impact.

👍 [b]Stunning atmosphere and visuals:[/b] Immersive world design that perfectly captures the bleakness of a frozen apocalypse.

👍 [b]Challenging resource management:[/b] Balancing survival and morality keeps gameplay engaging.

👍 [b]Endless replayability:[/b] With multiple scenarios and the Endless Mode, there's always a reason to come back.

👍 [b]Unique moral dilemmas:[/b] Your choices affect the survival of your people and shape your society.
[/td]
[/tr]

👎 [b]Limited scout interactions:[/b] Scouting missions can sometimes feel like a gamble, with high-risk and limited reward.

This is a citybuilder game. It has a circular ring design which is somewhat novel, and an aesthetic design which is somewhat unique and well put together. (skip to last paragraph for ADHD)

What this game really has [u]going[/u] for it is a really well structured and compelling narrative, which is also integrated into the visuals and audio (which are both really good). The reason the city is circular is because everybody is freezing to death and the (one) furnace is located in the center of the town, pumping heat out of the earth's core. The steampunk aesthetic almost couldn't be more narratively fitting, and the soundtrack has this dramatic string orchestra style that is just unbelievably gripping. (exaggeration)

The main problem is that this game is content short, it can be played in one 24 hour period during, say, semester finals (ask me how I know). There ultimately isn't very much game beyond the highly structured linear storyline. Also, I would say the 'society' progression system is flawed, it feels like the game wants you to progress to fanatical despotism but you can also just not do that? But then, you're just sitting there with a game notification telling you a decision can be made, but the decisions are "I AM THE MACHINE GOD", "IMPOSE THE WILL OF THE DEATH-STATE" or "MANDATORY SUPER-CANNIBALISM". Like, if you want to go with the flow of the game and just go crazy you can. But personally I wouldn't have minded some more 'moderate', or rather less insanely framed, policy progressions. If the author wanted players to pursue these policies I think they should have been narratively mandatory or something the player fights against trying to enforce.

The game also isn't that difficult but is very unforgiving if you haven't learned the systems. This is great narratively because the player can be 'burned' by their mistakes while trying to survive, matching the desperate scramble aesthetic of the whole game. But ultimately you are either doing things right, and the game is totally easy, or you aren't, and if you don't get it right bad enough you just have to reload. There aren't many design roadblocks, ways to play, or any real complexity to unravel or engage with. It's not like, a Sim City simulator where you're larping as a civil engineer grappling with road capacity equations or traffic flow schemas. There aren't really even meaningful logistics mechanisms or really anything to create ambiguity and potential for design variety.

Ultimately what I'm saying is that this game is an interactive movie, and the medium of interaction is a shallow but not un-enjoyable citybuilder. You'll love it if you want the story, but if you're into long-play citybuilding games this will probably be disappointing. I don't remember paying as much for this game as it is currently priced at, but on sale I couldn't possibly not recommend it. Also they're making a sequel! So if you want to know if that 60 dollar pre-order (lol) is worth it you should probably play its predecessor which is functionally its demo version.

Frostpunk is a standout in the city-building and survival genre, masterfully balancing simplicity with depth. At its core, the game presents basic mechanics: gather resources, manage heat, and keep your citizens alive. However, the beauty of Frostpunk lies in its complexity beneath the surface, making it easy to understand but extremely challenging to master. The game offers a perfect blend of resource management, exploration, and moral decision-making, all wrapped in a haunting, atmospheric narrative.

As someone who has spent many hours with Frostpunk, I found that once you get a handle on the mechanics—optimizing your city, keeping your citizens warm and fed, and managing their hope and discontent—it becomes a joy to return to again and again. While the game is relatively short (most of the content can be completed in about 30-40 hours, depending on how quickly you adapt to its challenges), it's the kind of game that pulls you back in for more. Even after mastering the gameplay, I love coming back to create my own little roleplaying scenarios, imagining new stories for the inhabitants of my city as they struggle through the frozen apocalypse.

The game may be intense, but that's part of the appeal. It's perfect for a few hours of highly engaging city-building where every decision counts. Whether you're experimenting with different laws, trying new strategies, or just seeing how long your city can last in the harsh environment, Frostpunk keeps you on your toes. It's a short, concentrated experience, but one that keeps you coming back for more—each return a fresh and intense challenge in a world on the brink of extinction.

The tension I felt as I beat the first scenario for the first time was amazing. This game is a very tight strategy puzzle, and a great narrative. Some city builders are about creating a balanced system, but this game will push your spinning plates and make you readjust on the fly. The iteration loop is hours long, and you can fail long before you get a game over. The interesting thing is the moment when you realize that you've messed up, and it's a hopeless situation. I really liked it; I felt pride, hope, shame, despair, fear and relief during my play through. For a jaded person like me, that means a lot. I can recommend this game to anyone who likes a relatively short strategy game with a strong aesthetic. However, if you want a game you can play forever or a power fantasy, it's not one of those.

[h1] A Genuinely Fantastic Video Game [/h1]

[i][Note: I already have 132 hours logged into this game on the xbox store version. Only bought on steam because it was on sale and I wanted to support the developer for creating this amazing game][/i]

Frostpunk has just the right amount of difficulty when it comes to strategy game. In fact, I would say this isn't really a strategy game, more like a city management game.
Yes, the events are very challenging and kinda depressing at times. But it also feels very fresh and rewarding at the end. The music is so damn good. And the cherry on top is that the story is pretty good as well.

I'm probably not going to log any extra hours on steam, I just had to log a few hours to be able to write this review, mainly because the next installment is due 6 days at the time of writing this review. I pray that game comes with decent optimization at launch. Thankfully it's on Game Pass so I won't have to spend extra money to buy at launch.

[h3] An easy 90% rating for me [/h3]

The raw food stores are running dangerously low. It is too cold to cook food; it stays frozen under the burners. The mines have shut down due to conditions that no amount of blood and flesh and death could overcome. The factories cannot produce enough prosthetics for the frostbitten. More and more take to the streets, demanding something to relieve them of the pain, but you can't give them anything. You are just as much of a bystander as they are. A family is found frozen solid inside their previously thought to be well heated and expertly insulated homes. 
The coal reserves are nigh but empty. The Generator cracks under the stress, and a panel of heat shielding shoots off inside your command station. 
Everyone is beginning to refuse to work, begging that they should at least be able to die with their loved ones. And yet...
The Generator continues to belch out steam. The Automatons carry out their endless, sleepless work. The restless mobs are held at bay through tyranny and zealotry and violence. Blood will be shed, but not in vain. 
The City will survive this. It has to. The City must survive.
Or else it would all be for naught.

Overall score: 8/10

The other scenarios have either a slightly different story or a slightly different story along with a slightly different UI/mechanics so there isn't a lot of difference between the scenarios. It definitely doesn't feel like a new game.

But the mechanics are fun and the slight story keeps you engaged to try to beat the scenario in your way. So definitely a game to try out for the main story and if you enjoyed that try the other scenarios to see if you like them.

Frostpunk is a lot like being born. Once you start, you can’t stop until you kill yourself. I have played this game every single year since it came out, usually around Christmas when I am alone and the drinking gets bad and I feel my liver popping out of my right side like Ernest Hemingway. Frostpunk is my only comfort. My menthol cigarette. My gái điếm in Khe Sanh. I would sooner kill a family of four behind the wheel of my 2005 Toyota Corolla than give up my Frostpunk habit.

I have spent most of my 25 years of life hoping against hope that I could be a tyrannical fascistic leader that would send children to work inside of a 150 degree celsisus generator. Frostpunk gives me what I’ve always wanted. To sacrifice children in the name of industrial progress.

Speaking of sacrifice, the fact that I can send five fathers to die inside of a wrecked piece of high technology, the likes of which humanity will likely never see again (as long as I am in charge), in search of a sketch of a flamingo or something like some New York yuppie really takes the experience up a notch.

One time, the game asked me if I would order a dying man’s arm amputated in an effort to save his life. I, of course, said yes, but insisted they amputate his legs as well. He died. Good.

If you are looking for a game that will transform not just your mind, but your very mortal soul in the image of George Nathaniel Curzon, this is the game for you.

Frostpunk combines many elements to form the game it is. It has survival, heavy resource management, decision making that affect your town and also a law system that further shapes your town (or more like survival pit) and can affect your people.

The immersion is outstanding, from the world, to the UI and a big factor for me, the music, plunge you in this time-critical game where your decisions matter and where there is never enough time to fully prepare yourself to survive what is coming. Some may consider this game stressful. I do too, but in a very good way.

Even though the game only has a set amount of scenarios that you can play through (and also an endless mode), I have never got bored of repeating said scenarios as every play-through kept me at the same level of scrambling for time to manage and gather my resources and develop for the upcoming temperature drops. 

Worth every penny even at full price however, the developers sometimes offer it as good discount as well.

Imagine the settlement as a character. You’re looking after it, growing its population, upgrading it, and keeping an eye on its health and temperature. Then you head off on a journey to rescue other survivors and bring them back to the camp. But the camp’s overflowing, resources are running low, and the temperature’s dropped sharply. Each night, someone dies. The graveyard’s too close to the homes, and it’s impossible to survive indoors. Despair just keeps mounting with every passing day.

Frostpunk is beautiful, the aesthetic is spot-on, and it very quickly sends you to a dark place of survival in a winter apocalypse. I like the mechanics and how the decisions you make for your settlement fork into other, more difficult, and often more dire, decisions that need to be made. I found the UI to be easy to understand and navigate and thought the controls and strategies were easy to pick up on.

However, this game suffers from something I have come to recognize (and despise) in other games and describe as 'artificial difficulty.' Artificial difficulty, at least the way I am going to describe it here, is difficulty that springs from the player not doing things exactly the way the game wants you to do it - basically, egregious amounts of trial and error. It is more akin to punishment than anything else. It became very obvious very quickly that Frostpunk forces you into certain pathways as far as what to build, research, and prioritize, or else you just lose. The repetitive, trial and error feeling comes from the fact that the scenarios seem to be 100% scripted, forcing you to anticipate what the next problem is going to be or else fail. This means that you end up having to memorize your way - one issue or problem at a time - through the play. This, quite simply, is just NOT fun for me. At all. Ever. 

I would expect a strategic game in this genre to have several ways to approach problems, but the lack of depth means that some strategies just don't work based on what the scenario is asking you to solve, and in what order. I wonder if a large portion of the buildings and/or research technologies are even worth it, but didn't play enough to get deep into the game to know for sure. When following the tutorial quests still ends up in you losing rather quickly, there is probably something wrong with game balance. It's a shame, because I wanted to like it. If you like the look and feel of it, buy it on sale and give it a try. But for those of you who want more strategic depth and freedom, I would probably urge a strong pass.

This was really fun city-building and management game until I realised that my sick children were actually returning to a tent they call home from 14-hour shift in the coal mines to eat a bowl of sawdust in -120°C, one of his parents working in the pleasure house and the other one was having his organs harvested and beign thrown into an organic fertiliser. All of that and I didn't even bat an eye because all I had was a goal in mind - the city must survive. It was only at the far end of the game when all was over that I suddenly realised the cost of this survival and my heart was burdened by a sense of guilt.

Not sure if it fits the city-builder genre since it's more about managing your resources and decision making as the game goes on, but certainly has some of those features. Do not expect SimCity but in Greenland.

The soundtrack was also very cool, especially "The Still, Cold World" and "The City Must Survive" tracks, love it. 

If you get this game make sure you get the additional scenarios too, each having a different themes, goals, challenges and moral dilemmas that are just as good, if not better than the main game. Truly awesome work.

You'll most likely have to retry some of the scenarios a couple of times before you figure it out, so if that's not your thing, then this is probably not going to be your kind of game. If this punishment sounds like your thing, then I wholeheartedly recommend this game to you.

As I was steaming an innocent man alive in the town square, his squirming and lobster-reddened corpse fried by the same generator that had kept us tenuously alive this past frozen age, I had a moment to wonder how I'd gotten here.  And I couldn't really say how my original goal of 'don't die' had led me to become the ruler of a cult of divinity out here in the arctic.  That's the magic of the game- it makes it easier to win if you do terrible things.  And it blurs the line between concepts like 'good' and 'evil' in a way that's interesting and realistic.  Is it really evil to kill a guy to save three hundred others?  What about just saving yourself?

Worth it for that moment alone.  The gameplay is tight, they don't spoon feed you success, and it's easy to die if you're not paying attention.  If you can beat the main campaign, you earned it.
It's an incredibly fun and challenging game, but allowing yourself to care about achievements will absolutely drive you up the wall because of how tedious a lot of them are.

Frostpunk is one of those games where you look at the environment you're tossed into and just feel immense guilt for the world around you.

This isn't just a City Builder type of game like City Skylines. No it's much more than that.
You are put in charge of a population in a dying world, there is not real "Victory" in this cold and unforgiving wasteland.

The world you knew before is Gone along with the green and warm summers, here there is only Frost and Death.
Both of which go hand in hand.

The Choices you have to make so that your people survive is astonishing to say the least, It's one of the few games where Child Labor is a need not a suggestion with no other alternative.

Sure you can try to save everyone, but in the end people will die and the real challenge is recovering from it and maintaining your control over this City.
The NPC's or Citizens in this game don't know what you're going through to make sure they survive, you're there for a greater purpose than a couple of Miners which died due to suffocation in the Coal Mines.

It's been said before, Survival is the only Goal. Whatever it takes and no price is to high.

Sympathy is punishable and dereliction is unacceptable, You must refuse to be led by your Morale Compass and instead choose to cover only the very needs of your population, as resources cannot be wasted.

As if you engage in Gluttony, You will come to know just how harsh Mother Nature can be..

It's a nice Steampunk-esque game. Really nice visuals, helpful tutorial. Still lost my first playthrough, but I'm learning. It'll happen. However, when perusing the settings, my eyes espied a particular option: temperature.

The game will let you choose which measurement systems to use. Excitedly, I clicked the right arrow: fahrenheit. I clicked again, celcius. I continued clicking, partially due to shock, partially due to amazement.

This game will not let you choose to us Kelvin as the thermal measurement unit.

So, I obviously have to say I cannot recommend this game, as it's obviously incomplete and is still waiting on the developers to finish adjusting settings, so that they can add an update to add Kelvin in. When they do, I am obviously going to be more than happy to change my recommendation. I just can't bring myself to do it, with the game in the incomplete state that it is in.

If you also want to try playing it, despite it's incomplete state, don't let me stop you. I'm just making sure that everyone knows the current state of things, and knows about some of the missing features. Thank you for reading, and have a pleasant day!

I'll throw in a recipe for Varenyky.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour – 500 g
Water – 200 ml
Egg – 1
Salt – 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes – 1 kg
Onions – 2
Lard or butter – 50 g
Salt – to taste
Ground black pepper – to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Sauté the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the sautéed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or sautéed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

To sum it up this is like a brutal, hardcore game of civilization 6 where you are building buildings and working plots  preparing for the temperature to drop even more! It's resource management at its finest.

One of the most brutally difficult strategy games I've ever played. On harder difficulties it requires high levels of engagement and micromanaging. Not the kind of city building game where you can just build stuff and wait for the resources to come in. It can take a lot of patience and restarting scenarios over and over again until you learn how to efficiently manage everything. It took me about 2 weeks of daily play (multiple hours a day) to finish the main scenario on hard on Xbox. Once you get the hang of it, it's not so bad. But if you're going at it blindly without any online guides or youtube tutorials, then be prepared for Dark Souls levels of difficulty.

oH, my goD. I wasn't sure about Frostpunk until I saw my roommate playing it, and that's coming from an avid city building game enjoyer. This is one of, scratch that, the BEST city building game I have ever played in my life. It takes resource management, risk/reward, foresight AND hindsight, compassion, dictatorship, altruism, and greed to succeed at any of the scenarios. You may think to abandon your moral compass to succeed, and sure the kids only lost a SINGLE hand in the sawmill, but you "won", right?  I have never been so sad that I had "succeeded" at a game due to its gripping commentary of what is necessary to "win". The setting and depiction of this world is so immersive, with what is actually just a drop of backstory, to make you feel like you are in this alternate 19th century dystopian timeline. I enjoyed this work so much that I have put 18 hours into it over the course of 2 days, and thats with a fulltime job. Speaking of, it is now 3am and I have work in 5 hours. I just couldn't say no to saving my people, I am their leader, and I shall be till the last snowflake falls.

They need to change how fast sick people get, or giving more engineers to treat them in extreme mode, because normal difficulty is too dull.

What I've realized is this game carries a very, very, very and extremely narrow path for doing things, almost as a cake receipt. In changing the order among the ingredients, you ruin the cake.

Problem is; it gets very, very dumb then, for it promises to be boring as hell. You get tired of the same cake taste.

So, this game is for people who doesn't like learning different ways to do things. You switch two buildings, fail. Switch two laws, fail. Switch the day and day time to build that particular and specific build, fail again.

You literaly HAVE TO sign or build at 5:00 in game.... that's too much demanding, that's just too dumb, because you kill the space for moving and enjoying. Think a RPG which you can only walk frontwards, never dodging, never jumping, never ducking, never hiting. Feels like a game for 5 y.o. to learn using a keyboard. "Press 'N'. Congratulations. Go to next fase now".

Much rather play age of empires, northgard, knights of honor, anno series, since developers made a very dumb strictly order list of doing things. Go play patience then, since you'll never be able to do something different.

Frostpunk is a great game, love the engaging challenge of the game that makes its grittiness a unique experience and its just challenging enough for it to feel fair and not just trauma-dumping. The world built around a very simple concept adds a ton of depth in each scenario, which in turn had me committing hours each time I booted up the game, and consistently losing track of time. As a base builder, Frostpunk carries itself pretty well within its genre as a game filled with unconventional conflicts, mitigated with thoughtful solutions.

**The graphics** is beautiful enough to achieve a truly immersive journey and the pacing of the story adds a lot of character to each scenario. (4/5)
**The gameplay** itself is very easy to pick up, making me feel adequately resourceful after a few hours of playing (4.8/5)
**The UI **is quite simple to navigate and **the engine** very rarely has any issues or bugs for me (4.3/5). 

I've been wanting to play this game for the longest time but couldn't persuade myself to pay $30 plus DLCs. A game of that value I expect replayability and to be quite honest, although this game is very immersive, captivating and very easy to lose track of time playing, I do believe that it's only replayable if you're personally motivated to do better in the four available scenarios. I do hope that they release the DLCs for free upon the release of Frostpunk 2 and I am looking forward to the advances they make in their sequel.

Overall score: 8.7/10
